conclusion: To solve for the magnitude of the external force F, we need to analyze the forces acting on the system of two sliders A and B.
Two sliders A and B are connected by a light rope and placed on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sliders and the inclined plane is μ = 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction.
It is known that sin 37° = 0.6, and the gravitational acceleration is g.
A constant horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right.
Both sliders are just on the verge of not sliding upwards.
Identify the forces acting on each slider.

Forces on Slider A: Gravitational force: mg (downward), Normal force from the incline: NA (perpendicular to the incline), Frictional force: fA (parallel to the incline, opposing motion), Tension in the rope: T (pulling up the incline).

Forces on Slider B: Gravitational force: mg (downward), Normal force from the incline: NB (perpendicular to the incline), Frictional force: fB (parallel to the incline, opposing motion), Tension in the rope: T (pulling down the incline), External horizontal force: F (to the right).
Resolve the forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the incline.

premise: For Slider A: Parallel component of gravity: mg sin 37° = 0.6mg, Perpendicular component of gravity: mg cos 37° = 0.8mg.
conclusion: The normal force NA balances the perpendicular component of gravity: NA = 0.8mg.
The frictional force fA is given by: fA = μ NA = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg.

premise: For Slider B: Parallel component of gravity: mg sin 37° = 0.6mg, Perpendicular component of gravity: mg cos 37° = 0.8mg.
conclusion: The normal force NB balances the perpendicular component of gravity: NB = 0.8mg.
The frictional force fB is given by: fB = μ NB = 0.5 × 0.8mg = 0.4mg.
Set up the equations of motion.
